ARTS-6211.courseDescription: is intended to give beginners a basic knowledge of the spoken and written language and culture of the German-speaking countries.

ARTS-6236.PR: GERM 2011 or the consent of the Head of Department
ARTS-6236.courseDescription: is a study of the chief periods of German literature based on works of representative authors. A general survey from 1750 to the present.

ARTS-6235.PR: GERM 2011 or the consent of the Head of Department
ARTS-6235.courseDescription: is a study of the chief periods of German literature based on works of representative authors. A general survey from the earliest works to 1750.

ARTS-6212.courseDescription: is a continuation of Elementary German I with the same basic text.

ARTS-6215.courseDescription: is a completion of the fundamentals of the German language, with a continued strong cultural component.

ARTS-6232.PR: GERM 3010 or consent of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6232.courseDescription: is a continuation of Advanced German I.

ARTS-6231.courseDescription: aims at a high level of accomplishment in German pronunciation, composition and translation through practice in the spoken language, written exercises and the reading of more advanced literary material.

ARTS-6216.PR: GERM 2010 or consent of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6216.courseDescription: is a grammar review and introduction to literature.

ARTS-6269.courseDescription: is a study of selected works of Russian authors of the pre-revolutionary, Soviet and post- Soviet periods. This course qualifies as a Research/Writing course.
ARTS-6269.courseTitle: Russian Literature in Translation: Twentieth Century
ARTS-6269.UL: may not be used as part of the Faculty of Arts requirement of 6 credit hours in a second language

ARTS-6239.courseDescription: is a study of the works of some major modern German authors. Lectures and readings in English.
ARTS-6239.courseTitle: Modern German Literature in Translation I (Pre-1945)

ARTS-6238.courseDescription: is a study of the legend of Faust's pact with the devil from the Middle Ages to the present in art, music and literature, and its influence on various cultures in both Europe and America. Lectures and readings in English.

ARTS-6234.PR: GERM 1001 and consent of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6234.courseDescription: aims to increase accuracy and fluency in written and spoken German with emphasis on grammar review.
ARTS-6234.OR: includes a four week field school in Germany in August, which lengthens the time frame for the course by approximately two weeks

ARTS-6233.PR: GERM 1001 and consent of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6233.courseDescription: aims to increase accuracy and fluency in written and spoken German with emphasis on culture.
ARTS-6233.OR: includes a 4- week field school in Germany in August, which lengthens the time frame for the course by approximately two weeks

ARTS-6279.courseDescription: explores contemporary issues concerning the changes (artistic, political, cultural, economic) and sense of rediscovery in modern Russia in the context of works by present-day writers.

ARTS-6264.courseDescription: is designed to foster a reading knowledge of Russian relevant to professional, business or academic disciplines. It is intended for senior undergraduate or graduate students, as well as professional and business people. No previous knowledge of Russian is required.

ARTS-6281.PR: one of RUSS 2011 , 2511 , 3011 , or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6281.courseDescription: is a study of major Russian authors, including Pushkin, Lermontov, and Gogol.
ARTS-6281.courseTitle: Russian Literature of the Nineteenth Century I

ARTS-6265.PR: RUSS 1000 or 1001 , or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6265.courseDescription: is a continuation of Russian for Reading I.

ARTS-6230.courseTitle: West to East: Aspects of the German Intellectual Influence on Russia

ARTS-7612.courseDescription: focuses on the oeuvres of one or two directors, or a movement or era within Soviet Cinema. Students will examine films closely according to their artistic structures and historical contexts, applying a broad range of classic readings on film theory to help inform analysis.

ARTS-6228.courseDescription: is an examination of East German cinema through its feature films addressing issues in the context of Germany's divided status and its split screen from 1946 to 1990.
ARTS-6228.courseTitle: DEFA The Cinema of East Germany

ARTS-6229.courseDescription: will have topics to be studied announced by the Department.
ARTS-6229.courseTitle: Special Topics in German Studies I

ARTS-6266.courseDescription: is an intensive course which focuses on improving vocabulary and fluency in speaking and writing Russian.

ARTS-6260.courseDescription: provides an introduction to Russian grammar and a basic knowledge of the spoken and written language.

ARTS-6261.courseDescription: is a continuation of Elementary Russian I.

ARTS-6248.PR: GERM 3011 or the consent of the Head of Department
ARTS-6248.courseDescription: is a study of the leading exponents of nineteenth-century literature, including the background of Poetic Realism and Naturalism. Taught in German.
ARTS-6248.courseTitle: German Literature of the 19th Century II

ARTS-6249.PR: GERM 3011 or the consent of the Head of Department
ARTS-6249.courseDescription: traces the important literary movements up to 1945, using a number of representative authors. Reading of selected dramas, novels, poems and short stories. This course is taught in German.
ARTS-6249.courseTitle: German Literature of the Twentieth Century I

ARTS-6221.PR: GERM 1001 and consent of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6221.courseDescription: is a continuation of Intermediate Composition and Conversation I.
ARTS-6221.OR: includes a 4- week field school in Germany in August, which lengthens the time frame for the course by approximately two weeks

ARTS-6222.courseDescription: is a study of the major cultural trends and movements of German-speaking Europe to the beginnings of the modern age. Lectures are given in English. This course qualifies as a research/writing course.

ARTS-6223.courseDescription: is a study of the major cultural trends and movements of German-speaking Europe in the modern age. Lectures are given in English. This course qualifies as a research/writing course.

ARTS-6242.courseDescription: examines German culture within the context of National Socialist era. Special attention will be focussed on how language, art and literature were used in National Socialist propaganda.

ARTS-6225.courseDescription: is a survey of German film from the beginnings to 1945.

ARTS-6226.courseDescription: is a survey of West German film from 1945 to 1990.

ARTS-6227.courseDescription: is a study of German cinema from 1990 to the present. It addresses a number of issues that are clearly identified with a post-Wall, unified Germany, such as German unification itself, the new German comedy of the 1990's, the transnationalization of German cinema, the treatment of the Nazi and the Communist past, the rediscovery of the social as a narrative focus, and on the evolving cinematographic directions taken by contemporary German film. The movies are subtitled and lectures and readings are in English.

ARTS-6263.courseDescription: s a continuation of Intermediate Russian I.

ARTS-6278.PR: one of RUSS 2011 , 2511 , 3011 , or permission of the Head of the Department

ARTS-6246.PR: GERM 4010 or consent of the Head of the Department.
ARTS-6246.courseDescription: is a continuation of Advanced Stylistics I. This course is taught in German.

ARTS-6247.PR: GERM 3011 or the consent of the Head of Department
ARTS-6247.courseDescription: is a study of the leading exponents of nineteenth-century literature, including the background of Romanticism and the young Germany movement. Taught in German.
ARTS-6247.courseTitle: German Literature of the 19th Century I

ARTS-6282.courseTitle: Russian Literature of the Nineteenth Century II

ARTS-6283.courseTitle: Russian Literature of the Twentieth Century I

ARTS-6280.courseDescription: will deal with topics as announced by the Department.

ARTS-6276.courseDescription: is a study of masterpieces by representative Russian authors of poetry and prose with particular emphasis on stylistic characteristics of the authors studied and the evolution of the Russian literary language.
ARTS-6276.UL: may not be used as part of the Faculty of Arts requirement of 6 credit hours in a second language

ARTS-6286.courseDescription: will deal with topics as announced by the Department.
ARTS-6286.courseTitle: Special Topics in Russian Studies II

ARTS-6244.PR: GERM 3011 or the consent of the Head of Department
ARTS-6244.courseDescription: is a study of the historical and cultural background of the eighteenth century, of Storm and Stress and Classicism. Reading and discussion of representative works with emphasis on Goethe and Schiller. Taught in German.
ARTS-6244.courseTitle: German Literature of the Eighteenth Century II

ARTS-6284.PR: one of RUSS 2011 , 2511 , 3011 , or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6284.courseDescription: is a study and analysis of texts by modern Russian writers.
ARTS-6284.courseTitle: Russian Literature of the Twentieth Century II

ARTS-6285.courseDescription: will deal with topics as announced by the Department.
ARTS-6285.courseTitle: Special Topics in Russian Studies I

ARTS-6245.PR: GERM 3011 or the consent of the Head of Department
ARTS-6245.courseDescription: is specialized study of the more complex areas of German grammar, style, and idiomatic usage, involving intensive practice in composition and oral expression, and focussed on detailed work with contemporary cultural materials such as newspapers, television, and film. This course is taught in German.

ARTS-6268.courseDescription: is a study of selected works of Russian authors including Pushkin, Lermontov, Gogol, Turgenev, Tolstoy, Dostoyevsky, Chekhov. This course qualifies as a Research/Writing course.
ARTS-6268.courseTitle: Russian Literature in Translation: Nineteenth Century
ARTS-6268.UL: may not be used as part of the Faculty of Arts requirement of 6 credit hours in a second language

ARTS-6256.courseDescription: is the comprehensive examination required for honours students.

ARTS-6243.PR: GERM 3011 or the consent of the Head of Department
ARTS-6243.courseDescription: is a study of the historical and cultural background of the eighteenth century, of Enlightenment and Storm and Stress. Reading and discussion of representative works with emphasis on Lessing, Goethe and Schiller. Taught in German.
ARTS-6243.courseTitle: German Literature of the Eighteenth Century I

ARTS-6273.courseTitle: West to East: Aspects of the German Intellectual Influence on Russia
ARTS-6273.UL: may not be used as part of the Faculty of Arts requirement of 6 credit hours in a second language

ARTS-6272.courseDescription: will deal with topics as announced by the Department.

ARTS-6271.courseDescription: is a study of the evolution of Russian culture in the USSR and the post-Soviet period. Lectures include discussions of Soviet Russian art, music and film. Lectures are given in English. This course qualifies as a Research/Writing course.
ARTS-6271.UL: may not be used as part of the Faculty of Arts requirement of 6 credit hours in a second language

ARTS-6270.courseDescription: is a study of the evolution of Russian culture and Russian intellectual history up to 1917. Lectures include discussions of Russian art, music and film. Lectures are given in English. This course qualifies as a Research/Writing course.
ARTS-6270.UL: may not be used as part of the Faculty of Arts requirement of 6 credit hours in a second language

ARTS-6277.PR: one of RUSS 2011 , 2511 , 3011 , or permission of the Head of the Department
ARTS-6277.courseDescription: is a study of masterpieces by representative Russian authors of poetry and prose with particular emphasis on stylistic characteristics of the authors studied and the evolution of the Russian literary language.

ARTS-6240.courseDescription: is a study of the works of some major modern German authors. Lectures and readings in English.
ARTS-6240.courseTitle: Modern German Literature in Translation II (Post-1945)

ARTS-6275.courseDescription: is a continuation of Advanced Russian I; emphasis is placed on advanced grammar and reading of selected texts from Russian short stores, magazines and newspapers.

ARTS-6274.courseDescription: is an advanced study of literary texts, grammar, composition and translation with practice in the spoken language.

ARTS-6255.courseDescription: will have topics to be studied announced by the Department.
ARTS-6255.courseTitle: Special Topics in German Studies II

ARTS-6257.courseDescription: is required as part of the Honours program.

ARTS-6241.PR: the former Women's Studies 2000 or permission of the Department Head
ARTS-6241.courseDescription: studies representative works by prominent German, Austrian, and Swiss women writers from the 19th-century to the present day, their place in German literary history, and the impact of their individual voices.
ARTS-6241.courseTitle: German Women Writers in English Translation

ARTS-6251.PR: one of German 2011 , 2511 , 3011 or the consent of the Head of Department
ARTS-6251.courseDescription: is an introduction to the German language, literature and culture of the eleventh to fifteenth centuries: historical linguistics, Middle High German grammar and the court epic.
ARTS-6251.courseTitle: Middle High German Language and Literature I

ARTS-6250.PR: GERM 3011 or the consent of the Head of Department
ARTS-6250.courseDescription: traces the important post 1945 literary movements, using a number of representative authors. Reading of selected dramas, novels, poems and short stories. This course is taught in German.
ARTS-6250.courseTitle: German Literature of the Twentieth Century II

ARTS-6253.PR: one of German 2011 , 2511 , 3011 or the consent of the Head of Department
ARTS-6253.courseDescription: is reading, interpretation and critical analysis of representative works of German literature written in the Age of Reformation and the early Baroque period.

ARTS-6252.courseTitle: Middle High German Language and Literature II
